title: Ed Woodward backs Ole Gunnar Solskjaer in defiant message against Manchester United’s critics
text:
Ed Woodward has backed Ole Gunnar Solskjaer despite Manchester United’s poor start to the season (Picture: Getty)

Ed Woodward has offered a defiant backing to his under-pressure manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer despite Manchester United’s miserable start to the season.

United have won only two of their opening eight Premier League matches and are hovering just two points above the relegation zone ahead of Sunday’s meeting with table-topping Liverpool at Old Trafford.

The team’s slump under Solskjaer stretches back to the end of last season after he was appointed on a permanent basis in March as they have won only five of their last 23 matches in all competitions.

Despite the club’s current problems, Woodward is adamant that Solskjaer is the right man for the job as his footballing philosophy and values mirror that of the club.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer is under pressure following a difficult start to the season (Picture: Getty)

‘Ole’s vision maps exactly to the core three football objectives we have: we must win trophies, we must play attacking football, and we must give youth its chance,’ Woodward told club staff.

‘The middle section of last season, after Ole’s arrival, feels most relevant to what we want to achieve and where we want to be, we saw a team playing fast, fluid football, with a clear representation of the style and philosophy the manager wants.’

Despite United’s underwhelming performances in the latter stages of the 2018-19 campaign, Solskjaer was able to boost his squad with the signings of Harry Maguire, Aaron Wan-Bissaka and Daniel James in the summer for a combined £145m.

Woodward believes that those additions will prove to be valuable ones to United in the long-term and also aimed a dig at the likes of Romelu Lukaku and Alexis Sanchez by suggesting that they lacked respect for the club’s history.

Woodward appeared to aim a dig at Romelu Lukaku and Alexis Sanchez who left United to join Inter in the summer (Picture: Getty)

‘Ole has also instilled the discipline back into an environment where we may have lacked it in recent years,’ he said. ‘He is building a squad that respects the club’s history, in which players work hard and respect their team-mates.

‘No one is bigger than the club. The changes we saw over the summer have resulted in a very young squad. But it’s also a squad, with the players and the culture, that provides a base camp for us to build and grow from as we start our new journey.’

A frequent criticism of Woodward during his six-year spell as the club’s CEO has been that he has prioritized commercial success to on-field matters by securing a number of lucrative sponsorship deals while the team has struggled.

He denied that is the case, though, saying: ‘The reality of Manchester United is we are a club in two parts.

‘First of all, we are an incredible 141-year footballing institution with all that history, all that legacy, all that tradition and that tradition of success. That can never, ever change. We need to keep that protected.

‘Then, like other football clubs, our commercial business allows us to reinvest in the football side. It’s how these two interact with each other at Manchester United that results in us having a competitive advantage in this area.

‘What’s important is the commercial side is never allowed to take priority over the football side.’
